      <title>Facebook trends: Zuckerberg invites top conservatives to talk and denies bias</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/zuckerberg-denies-facebook-bias-invites-conservatives-talk</link>
      <description><p>As Facebook battles a report accusing it of suppressing conservative news, CEO says he plans to ‘invite leading conservatives ... to share their point of view’</p><p>Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg has announced that he plans to invite “leading conservatives and people from across the political spectrum” to talk with him about accusations of political bias at the social media company.</p><p>Zuckerberg made the announcement Thursday evening in a <a href="https://www.facebook.com/zuck/posts/10102830259184701">Facebook post</a> that continued to deny the allegations of bias and the claim that the Facebook trending topics team suppresses conservative news. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/zuckerberg-denies-facebook-bias-invites-conservatives-talk">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Apple invests $1bn in Didi Chuxing, China's Uber rival</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/13/apple-didi-chuxing-china-uber-rival</link>
      <description><p>Tim Cook says investment – single largest ever in Chinese ride-hailing service – allows Apple to learn more about the market there </p><p>Apple has invested $1bn in Didi Chuxing, China’s version of Uber, CEO Tim Cook said on Thursday.</p><p>Ahead of a high-profile visit to the country later in May, Cook told <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/us-apple-china-idUSKCN0Y404W">Reuters</a> that the investment would create opportunities to partner with Didi – fuelling speculation that Apple is making a strategic investment that complements its own plans for a new electric car.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/13/apple-didi-chuxing-china-uber-rival">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How Silverstring Media  fought GamerGate and ADHD to make compelling games</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/13/silverstring-gamergate-adhd-compelling-games</link>
      <description><p>For four months, this Vancouver studio was at the centre of an internet maelstrom. But it had overcome bigger challenges </p><p><em>“Recent events have thrust our company under a spotlight …” </em>It was with those words, in September 2014, that Lucas J W Johnson, one of the founding members of Silverstring Media, began <a draggable="true" href="http://silverstringmedia.com/news/2014/9/1/intent-and-ideology">a blogpost about his company</a>. “Under a spotlight”, it turned out, was something of an understatement. Silverstring Media had been targeted by the burgeoning online movement GamerGate, a loose affiliation of Twitter, Reddit and game forums users claiming to expose and protest corruption in the video games media. The company was accused of being “corrupt” and “creepy”, supposedly pushing ideologies and cultish practices that worked towards taking “the fun out of video games”. Connections were established between Silverstring and the original GamerGate target <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/jan/11/gamergate-a-brief-history-of-a-computer-age-war">Zoe Quinn</a>. Then everything snowballed.</p><p>“[GamerGaters] got it into their heads that Silverstring Media was a PR firm, and that as such we must have been behind a conspiracy to release a series of ‘<a href="http://kotaku.com/we-might-be-witnessing-the-death-of-an-identity-1628203079">gamers</a> <a href="http://dangolding.tumblr.com/post/95985875943/the-end-of-gamers">are</a> <a href="https://www.buzzfeed.com/josephbernstein/gaming-is-leaving-gamers-behind">dead</a>’ articles all at once from multiple different venues,” Johnson said. “As conspiracies do, that then spiralled into further corruption with the Digital Games Research Association (DiGRA), and eventually allegations that we work with the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (Darpa). We became ‘the final boss’ of GamerGate, responsible for all their woes.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/13/silverstring-gamergate-adhd-compelling-games">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Second bank hit by 'sophisticated' malware attack, says Swift</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/13/second-bank-hit-by-sophisticated-malware-attack-says-swift</link>
      <description><p>The financial messaging network says a commercial bank was targeted in an attack with ‘deep knowledge of operational controls’</p><p>Swift, the global financial messaging network that banks use to move billions of dollars every day, warned on Thursday of a second malware attack similar to the one that led to February’s<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/15/bangladesh-central-bank-governor-resigns-over-81m-dollar-cyber-heist"> $81 million cyberheist </a>at the Bangladesh central bank.</p><p>The second case targeted a commercial bank, Swift spokeswoman Natasha de Teran said, without naming it. It was not immediately clear how much money, if any, was stolen in the second attack. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/13/second-bank-hit-by-sophisticated-malware-attack-says-swift">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Hyperloop or over-hyped? Latest demo does little to ease doubts</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/hyperloop-or-over-hyped-latest-demo-does-little-to-ease-doubts</link>
      <description><p>Don’t count your chickens before they’re accelerated at 1,200km an hour down a modified railgun through a vacuum tube</p><p>The future of transportation is here! Deep in the Nevada desert on Wednesday morning, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/11/hyperloop-supersonic-train-test-propulsion-system">a linear accelerator propelled a small sled</a> along a purpose-built test track to a speed of almost 187km/h in just over a second. It may just be a very early test but, the assembled media assured us, it means that the Hyperloop – the utopian transport system first mooted by technology entrepreneur Elon Musk – in 2013 is <a draggable="true" href="http://time.com/4325946/hyperloop-one-test/?utm_source=feedburner&amp;utm_medium=feed&amp;utm_campaign=Feed%3A+timeblogs%2Fcurious_capitalist+%28TIME%3A+Business%29">one</a> <a draggable="true" href="http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-05/12/c_135353417.htm">step</a> <a draggable="true" href="http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2016-05/12/c_135353417.htm">closer</a> <a draggable="true" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/05/11/elon-musks-most-ambitious-idea-just-came-one-step-closer-to-reality/">to reality</a>.</p><p>Except, well, it doesn’t. The test shows that Hyperloop One has reached the technological heights of <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_of_Fear">a 1996-era rollercoaster</a> when it comes to its propulsion systems, but does nothing to calm very real doubts that the company will be able to deliver what it promises, when it promises, for the price it promises.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/hyperloop-or-over-hyped-latest-demo-does-little-to-ease-doubts">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Is the Assassin's Creed movie actually going to be good?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/assassins-creed-movie-michael-fassbender-good</link>
      <description><p>The first trailer was released on Wednesday, showing Michael Fassbender donning the assassin’s hood. It shows promise, but we’ve been here before</p><p>Video game movie adaptation. It’s a phrase likely to strike fear and dread into the heart of most gamers, and indeed most moviegoers. Street Fighter, Super Mario Bros, Silent Hill, Hitman. All of these classic, hugely acclaimed video games have been thrust onto the big screen (or the straight-to-DVD shelves) by people whose knowledge of the source materials seems to have been passing at best. The results have been ... horrible.</p><p>Assassin’s Creed, we are being told, is a different story. Produced by Ubisoft, the company that developed and published the bestselling games, it has actual star actors (Michael Fassbender, Marion Cotillard, Jeremy Irons) and a talented director in the form of Justin Kurzel, who made the award-winning Snowtown and helmed Fassbender’s gritty Macbeth movie. For once this isn’t a bunch of Hollywood chancers hoping to cash in on a successful gaming brand; it’s the game makers themselves, overseeing their vision as a motion picture spectacle. The Assassin’s Creed titles have apparently been referenced closely by the production team, with the prop makers studying 3D representations of every weapon and costume. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/assassins-creed-movie-michael-fassbender-good">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Battlefield 1: is it wrong to set a war game in the trenches of the first world war?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/battlefield-war-game-first-world-war</link>
      <description><p>We are comfortable with a cartoon portrayal of Allies versus Nazis. It’s not much worse to gamify the Great War</p><p>The first world war may not be the most obvious time period in which to set a team-based first-person shooter with a heavy emphasis on vehicular combat.</p><p>The pointless slaughter of trench warfare, with lines of enlisted men marching slowly towards machine guns that mowed them down by the thousands, all to gain or lose mere feet of frontline, isn’t exactly a “fun” scenario.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/battlefield-war-game-first-world-war">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>How can I provide guests with Wi-Fi without giving them my password?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/2016/may/12/how-can-i-provide-guests-with-wi-fi-without-giving-them-my-password</link>
      <description><p>Noel intends to register on AirBnB and wants to offer porn-free internet access without giving away all his security details</p><p><em>I intend to register on AirBnB and I’d like to know how to share my fibre optic internet connection safely, without giving out the main Wi-Fi password. I believe some routers have guest access features, but not the one I use: a BT Home Hub 3. I am also thinking about OpenDNS as an additional option to screen out pornography etc. I am open to buying another router if necessary.</em> <strong>Noel</strong></p><p>This is a topic that should interest people renting out their homes and small businesses that want to offer clients free Wi-Fi access – I wish my dentist did, for example.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/askjack/2016/may/12/how-can-i-provide-guests-with-wi-fi-without-giving-them-my-password">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Instagram unveils new logo, but it's not quite picture perfect</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/11/instagram-new-logo-photo-sharing-app</link>
      <description><p>Photo sharing app unveils new sunset-coloured logo and a sleeker in-app look, but opinion is mixed</p><p>Instagram, the photo sharing app owned by Facebook, responsible for such cultural highlights as <a href="https://www.instagram.com/hotdoglegs/">hot-dog legs</a>, <a href="https://www.instagram.com/thefatjewish/">The Fat Jewish memes</a> and <a href="https://www.instagram.com/richkidsofinstagram/?hl=en">Rich Kids of, well, Instagram</a>, has debuted a new logo.</p><p>The previous one, a retro-looking camera, and one of the most recognisable tech logos out there, has been replaced by a background swirl of sunset colours (orange, yellow, pink, purple) and a white outline of a camera. As if the camera was murdered, and chalk was drawn around its body. Murdered at sundown. Here it is:</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/11/instagram-new-logo-photo-sharing-app">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Stop telling us to switch off – we live in a digital culture now | Suzanne Moore</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/commentisfree/2016/may/11/stop-telling-us-to-switch-off-we-live-in-a-digital-culture-now</link>
      <description><p>France is encouraging employees to disconnect from work at weekends but why is the narrative around our online lives so punitive? Being connected is our lifeline</p><p>I left my house without my phone the other day and could not be bothered to go back to get it. “Sure, I can be totally disconnected for a day,” I thought to myself. “It will be good for me.”</p><p>It’s a long time since I have been phoneless. It’s not as if I am a teenager who feels her phone to be a necessary limb, is it? It would surely mean that I would be truly in the moment; not distracted by social-media froth, not needing to know the news as it happens, unable to answer emails or text various offspring my various and inane instructions. Instead, I would be in the world, communicating deeply and authentically with it. Poor world. For I awaited this cliched epiphany of disconnection. I wanted to say that everything was more meaningful now that I was no longer “elsewhere” (ie online). I wanted to feel the moral superiority, or at least maturity, of those people who proudly announce they don’t do Facebook/Twitter/Instagram in the same way they once would have announced they didn’t watch TV.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/commentisfree/2016/may/11/stop-telling-us-to-switch-off-we-live-in-a-digital-culture-now">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Six reasons why everyone is hating on Call of Duty</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/11/call-of-duty-infinite-warfare</link>
      <description><p>The trailer for Call of Duty: Infinite Warfare title has been disliked more than a million times. What has happened to the world’s favourite shooter?</p><p>They’ve seen things you people wouldn’t believe. Attack ships on fire in Earth’s outer orbit. Cities blasted to rubble by invading battle craft. And how have they reacted to these precious moments? By down-voting the absolute crap out of them on YouTube.</p><p>Yes, this is the news that the trailer for the latest Call of Duty title – the modestly named Infinite Warfare – has received a record number of dislikes on the video-sharing platform. Right now the figure stands at 1,689,649, a hate benchmark that social scientists are calling “well into Justin Bieber territory”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/11/call-of-duty-infinite-warfare">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Facebook news selection is in hands of editors not algorithms, documents show</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/facebook-trending-news-leaked-documents-editor-guidelines</link>
      <description><p><strong>Exclusive:</strong> Leaked internal guidelines show human intervention at almost every stage of its news operation, akin to a traditional media organization</p><p>Leaked documents show how Facebook, now the biggest news distributor on the planet, relies on old-fashioned news values on top of its algorithms to determine what the hottest stories will be for the 1 billion people who visit the social network every day.</p><p>The documents, given to the Guardian, come amid growing concerns over how Facebook decides what is news for its users. This week the company was accused of an <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/09/facebook-newsfeed-censor-conservative-news">editorial bias against conservative news organizations</a>, prompting <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/10/facebook-trending-conservative-news-senate-committee-letter">calls for a congressional inquiry</a> from the US Senate commerce committee chair, John Thune.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/facebook-trending-news-leaked-documents-editor-guidelines">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>YouGov’s online poll comes amid claims in US that site’s staff working on its trending articles feature censored rightwing news</p><p>People in the UK from across the political spectrum think that they see more leftwing news on Facebook than stories from neutral or rightwing sources, according to a YouGov poll. </p><p>The <a href="https://yougov.co.uk/news/2016/05/12/facebook-left-wing-echo-chamber/">findings from an online poll </a>come as a debate rages in the US over <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/10/facebook-trending-conservative-news-senate-committee-letter">allegations</a> that Facebook staff working on its trending articles feature censored rightwing news. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/people-think-there-is-more-leftwing-news-on-facebook-says-study">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Twitter bars spy agencies from buying bulk user data from analytics firm</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/09/twitter-surveillance-fbi-cia-privacy-dataminr</link>
      <description><p>Social network says it has ‘never authorized’ Dataminr to sell information to US intelligence agencies, but officials say tools have been used previously</p><p>Twitter has blocked US spies from buying bulk data on its users from a data analytics company.</p><p>Until now, US national security agencies, including the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/fbi">FBI</a> and CIA, had been able to parse treasure troves of Twitter data through software from Dataminr, the New York-based analytics company in which Twitter owns a 5% stake. Agents could enter key terms such as “Isis” or “jihad” and receive alerts for relevant posts, people familiar with the process said.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/09/twitter-surveillance-fbi-cia-privacy-dataminr">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/call-of-duty-activision-facebook-esports-twitch-instagram</link>
      <description><p>World’s largest computer game publisher also hopes broadcasts on Twitch and Instagram will help take e-sports mainstream<br></p><p>The world’s largest computer game publisher, Activision Blizzard, is hoping to use Facebook’s live video to turn e-sports into a mainstream attraction, and make the people who play computer games competitively into the next sporting stars.</p><p>In New York on Thursday the company announced a slew of improvements to its e-sports platforms, which host video of competitive gamers playing titles such as Call of Duty or Starcraft. The company’s most popular event to date was the Major Championship of first-person shooter Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, which attracted 71m live and on-demand views. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/may/12/call-of-duty-activision-facebook-esports-twitch-instagram">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Telecoms firm reveals cost of attack hit £42m, cutting its profits from £32m to £14m</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/talk-talk-telecom">TalkTalk</a> profits more than halved following a cyber-attack in which the personal details of thousands of customers were hacked.</p><p>The telecoms company was hit with £42m in costs when <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/nov/06/nearly-157000-had-data-breached-in-talktalk-cyber-attack">almost 157,000 customers were affected by the attack in October last year</a>.       <title>Hacker collects 272m email addresses and passwords, some from Gmail</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/04/gmail-yahoo-email-password-hack-hold-security</link>
      <description><p>Security firm announces it has persuaded fraudster to give up database of email addresses along with passwords users use to log in to websites</p><p>The internet on Wednesday gave you another reminder that everyone has been hacked. </p><p>Hold Security, a Wisconsin-based security firm famous for obtaining hoards of stolen data from the hacking underworld, announced that it had persuaded a fraudster to give them a database of 272m unique email addresses along with the passwords consumers use to log in to websites. The escapade was detailed in a <a draggable="true" href="http://www.reuters.com/article/us-cyber-passwords-idUSKCN0XV1I6">Reuters article</a>. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/04/gmail-yahoo-email-password-hack-hold-security">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Ten-year-old receives $10,000 reward for finding Instagram bug</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/03/instagram-comment-bug-10-year-old-hacking-finland-reward</link>
      <description><p>A Finnish boy is the youngest person to get payout for finding bug that allowed comments to be deleted – and says he’ll use the money to buy a football and bike<br></p><p>Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg didn’t even begin to learn programming until he got a tutor at 11 years old – so he may have met his match in a 10-year-old Finnish schoolboy who has received a $10,000 bounty from Facebook after finding a vulnerability in Instagram’s code.</p><p>Instagram, which was bought by Facebook in 2012 for $1bn, is part of the Facebook “bug bounty” program, created in 2011, under which people who spot chinks in Facebook’s digital armour are given a reward. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/03/instagram-comment-bug-10-year-old-hacking-finland-reward">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Supreme court grants FBI massive expansion of powers to hack computers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/29/fbi-hacking-computers-warrants-supreme-court-congress</link>
      <description><p>Intelligence committee senator said he plans to introduce bill to block expansion to ‘rule 41’ on warrants for suspects who hide their location, set for December</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2014/oct/29/fbi-powers-hacking-computers-surveillance">FBI demands new powers to hack into computers and carry out surveillance</a></li></ul><p>The US Congress has seven months to block a potentially massive expansion of the government’s ability to hack into suspects’ computers. </p><p>At the FBI’s request this week, the <a href="http://www.supremecourt.gov/orders/courtorders/frcr16_8mad.pdf">supreme court ruled</a> that federal judges should be able to issue hacking warrants to federal law enforcement for anywhere in the US if the suspect has tried to hide their location, as criminal suspects are wont to do. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/29/fbi-hacking-computers-warrants-supreme-court-congress">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>FBI bought $1m iPhone 5C hack, but doesn't know how it works</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/29/fbi-bought-1m-iphone-5c-hack-but-doesnt-know-how-it-works</link>
      <description><p>US law enforcement agency in possession of mechanism for unlocking iPhone 5Cs or older – but identity of hackers closely guarded secret</p><p>The FBI doesn’t know how the hack used to unlock the San Bernardino shooter’s iPhone 5C works, and yet it paid in the region of $1m for the mechanism, which can used again to unlock any other iPhone 5C running iOS 9, according to reports.</p><p>Several US government <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/us-apple-encryption-idUSKCN0XQ032">sources told Reuters</a> that the amount paid for the hack, bought from professional hackers, was substantially less than previous reports indicating a value over $1.3m. The technique can also be used as many times as needed without further payments.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/29/fbi-bought-1m-iphone-5c-hack-but-doesnt-know-how-it-works">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>FBI confirms it won't tell Apple how it hacked San Bernardino shooter's iPhone</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/27/fbi-apple-iphone-secret-hack-san-bernardino</link>
      <description><p>Bureau will not tell Apple about <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/13/fbi-reportedly-paid-professional-hackers-gain-access-san-bernardino-iphone">the security flaw it exploited</a> to break into the iPhone 5C, in part because it didn’t buy the rights to the technical details</p><p>When the FBI <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/21/fbi-apple-iphone-hack-san-bernardino-price-paid">bought a hacking tool</a> to break into an iPhone, it wasn’t sure what exactly it got for its $1.3m.</p><p>On Wednesday, the FBI confirmed it wouldn’t tell Apple about the security flaw it exploited to break inside the iPhone 5C of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/feb/17/inside-the-fbis-encryption-battle-with-apple">San Bernardino gunman Syed Farook</a> in part, because the bureau says it didn’t buy the rights to the technical details of the hacking tool. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/27/fbi-apple-iphone-secret-hack-san-bernardino">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Shame hacking: attack on dating site for 'beautiful people' is actually pretty scary</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/25/shame-hack-beautiful-people-ashley-madison-online-dating</link>
      <description><p>BeautifulPeople.com boasts ‘online dating for beautiful people only’, and at first there’s a joy to watching the mighty fall. But it could happen to any of us <br></p><p>There’s a schadenfreude to the news today that the dating site <a href="https://www.beautifulpeople.com/en-UK">BeautifulPeople.com</a> was hacked. </p><p>It’s a site that only lets in the genetically blessed based on some mysterious beauty metric – and <a href="http://www.wired.com/2016/04/beautiful-people-hack/">today the personal data of 1.1 million BeautifulPeople.com members is for sale on the black market</a>. It’s only a slice of data from 2015, and the company says the leak’s been patched up, but data once stolen can never be controlled: and so 1.1 million names of self-declared Beautiful People will now begin circulating. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/25/shame-hack-beautiful-people-ashley-madison-online-dating">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Facebook corporate network hack discovered by security researcher</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/25/facebook-corporate-network-hack-security</link>
      <description><p>Penetration testing unearths backdoor installed on Facebook’s company servers had been logging employee credentials and exposing security </p><p>Hackers gained entry to Facebook’s internal corporate network for several months, with access to hundreds of the social network’s employee usernames and passwords.<br></p><p>The hackers, which were actively exploiting Facebook’s network in July and September last year and possibly as recently as February this year, were discovered by a security researcher performing penetration testing on Facebook’s corporate network.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/25/facebook-corporate-network-hack-security">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>When it comes to interracial romances, the movies need to catch up</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/when-it-comes-to-interracial-romances-the-movies-need-to-catch-up</link>
      <description><p>Almost 50 years after Kirk and Uhura’s kiss on Star Trek, there are plenty of parts for black women - provided they want to play blue- or green-skinned aliens …</p><p>“Interspecies love is in the air!” enthuses <a href="http://teaser-trailer.com/warcraft-movie-anduin-lothar-and-garona-halforcen/">one movie fansite</a> at the prospect of the forthcoming Warcraft movie.</p><p>There’s a lot to get up to speed with in Warcraft. The original video games were so wildly popular that their community of players exceeds the population of Norway, and the <a href="http://wowwiki.wikia.com/wiki/Portal:Main">World of Warcraft wiki</a> has over 100,000 pages. For novices, it’s a fantasy world not far removed from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/lord-of-the-rings">Lord of the Rings</a> or Dungeons and Dragons: a realm of elves, dwarves, mythical creatures and medieval weaponry. Warcraft the movie revolves around Azeroth, a kingdom apparently ruled by European humans. Azeroth is invaded by orcs: hulking, relatively primitive ogres with overdeveloped lower canines. Rather than open arms, Azeroth greets these refugee orcs with medieval arms. “They’re beasts. They should all be destroyed,” says one character. It’s essentially a race war, although the battle lines are by no means cut and dried, so there’s still room for a bit of interspecies love.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/when-it-comes-to-interracial-romances-the-movies-need-to-catch-up">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Uncharted 4 and the grief of finishing a great video game</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/10/uncharted-4-grief-finishing-video-game-loss-novel-tv</link>
      <description><p>A sense of loss often follows our reaching the end of a gripping novel or TV series, but in games our interaction with the characters can make the feeling deeper</p><p>When my son was coming to the end of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, having avidly consumed the previous six books in the series, his progress noticeably slowed. He’d go days, weeks even, before finishing a chapter – so much so that we thought that he was going off the story altogether. But he wasn’t. He was drawing it out. Like millions of other fans, he simply could not face leaving Hogwarts. Harry, Ron and Hermione had become more than characters: they were friends. He cried when he read the epilogue, “19 years later”.</p><p>This is a common phenomenon with very good books, and with television series too: the characters become so habitual and beloved over time that we form relationships with them, often augmented by the way we avidly discuss each instalment with friends and in online forums. In 2014, Cristel Russell, an associate professor at the American University’s Kogod School of Business, completed a study entitled When Narrative Brands End: The Impact of Narrative Closure and Consumption Sociality on Loss Accommodation, which argued that fans effectively go through a mourning process when a good show or book series comes to a close. We have to learn to let go.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/10/uncharted-4-grief-finishing-video-game-loss-novel-tv">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Shrill: Notes from a Loud Woman by Lindy West – ‘I never wanted internet trolls to be my beat’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/13/shrill-notes-from-a-loud-woman-lindy-west-review</link>
      <description><p>West’s memoir is full of a wild, joyous vulgarity and ranges from body images and rape threats to puberty and her love for her husband</p><p>In 2013, Lindy West got a message on Twitter from her dead father. “Embarrassed father of an idiot,” his bio said. But no: “My dad was never mean. It couldn’t really be&nbsp;from him. Also, he was dead – just 18 months earlier, I’d&nbsp;watched him turn grey and drown in his own magnificent lungs.” Someone wanted to hurt her.</p><p>At that moment in her career, West was fielding daily online harassment for her opposition to rape jokes in standup comedy. “I was eating 30 rape threats for breakfast at that point (or, more accurately, ‘You’re fatter than the girls I usually rape’ threats),” she writes in this memoir. “No one could touch me any more.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/13/shrill-notes-from-a-loud-woman-lindy-west-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/changeling-review-toddler-technical-skills</link>
      <description><p>Aleks Krotoski focuses on the emotional impact in this debate on how technology is changing too fast for parents to keep up</p><p>‘Scary, intimidating. Are these the words we want to be using to describe how our kids are using technology?” asks the ever-enthralling Aleks Krotoski in <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b079nfz6" title=""><strong>Changeling</strong></a>. Previous episodes of Radio 4’s absorbing <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01n7094" title="">Digital Human series</a> have focused on taste, body and mind and they’re all worth a listen. Now, talk turns to the contentious issue of children being better at using technology than their parents.</p><p>Krotoski always brings out the human emotion behind the digital story and she has no problem firing up the most paranoid part of a parent’s brain with this debate. That moment when you realise your child can unlock your tablet also unlocks peace and quiet, but what happens when the terror of your three-year-old overtaking your technical skills kicks in?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2016/may/12/changeling-review-toddler-technical-skills">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Alice Through the Looking Glass review – second trip to Underland is far from wondrous</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/10/alice-through-the-looking-glass-review-johnny-depp-mia-wasikowska</link>
      <description><p>The 2010 Alice in Wonderland movie boasted some gothic magic courtesy of Tim Burton. The James Bobin-directed sequel is uninspired in comparison</p><p>When <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/mar/04/alice-in-wonderland-review">Alice in Wonderland</a>, Tim Burton’s live-action take on Lewis Carroll’s children’s classic, opened in the spring of 2010, cutting-edge 3D was a relatively new phenomenon. Avatar had broken records that winter, setting the bar for the blockbusters that would follow. Audiences craving an experience similar to James Cameron’s space jam flocked to Burton’s film, which also promised viewers an immersive journey to a magical world. The fact that the picture was mauled by critics didn’t seem to deter audiences.</p><p>After it grossed $1bn worldwide, a sequel was all but inevitable. What’s surprising is how long it’s taken. On the evidence of Alice Through the Looking Glass, Disney didn’t use the time to iron out the kinks that made the first instalment so lacklustre. Instead, the studio has managed to deliver a follow-up that’s even weaker than its predecessor. In crude terms: Alice’s second trip to Underland wasn’t worth the wait.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/10/alice-through-the-looking-glass-review-johnny-depp-mia-wasikowska">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Bowman Pilgrims: bike preview | Martin Love</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/08/bowman-pilgrims-bike-preview-observer-martin-love</link>
      <description><p>Eye-catching and robust, the Pilgrims from Bowman is a lot tougher than it looks</p><p>Cycling into the office the other day my eye was caught by the bike of a fellow rider. It was a proper head-turner – anodised paint job, tapered carbon forks, T-section top tube – and a brand I hadn’t heard of: Bowman. I guessed it was one of those poncey pricey frames that bankrupt you and then leave you too terrified to actually enjoy it. But it turns out Bowman builds rugged, rideable frames for the year-round, no-nonsense cyclist. The firm is the brainchild of Neil Webb who, after 20 years in the industry, decided to go it alone. His bikes are designed at his base on the outskirts of southeast London and then built in Taiwan. There are currently five models, each named after a landmark familiar to cyclists in the southeast– Palace, Pilgrims, Foots Cray and Layhams. This one is the Pilgrims (named after the Pilgrims’ Way). It features generous ‘RoadPlus’ geometry which gives you the clearance to fit wider tyres or mudguards so you can swap in bigger rubber and turn off the road to tackle trails. In all you’ll get bespoke looks for Sundays, but a sturdy worker for weekdays (<a href="https://bowman-cycles.com/product/pilgrims/"><em>Bowman Cyles</em></a>).</p><p><strong>Price: £750 (frameset only, complete bikes from £1,500)<br></strong><strong>Frame: 7005-T6 aluminium<br></strong><strong>Forks: tapered carbon<br></strong><strong>Brakes: post mount discs<br></strong><strong>Hidden Guard Mounts</strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/may/08/bowman-pilgrims-bike-preview-observer-martin-love">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Pinpoint by Greg Milner review – how is GPS changing our world?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/04/pinpoint-how-gps-is-changing-our-world-greg-milner-review</link>
      <description><p>Anyone with a smartphone anywhere on Earth knows exactly where they are. But does that leave us lost?</p><p>In early 2008, for quixotic reasons that needn’t detain us here, I decided to walk from Dubai airport across the city and into the Empty Quarter of Arabia. Prior to departure, at home in London, I tried to figure out a way of reaching, on foot, the desert resort of Bab al Shams, which lay about 15 miles beyond the city’s ragged fringe of buy-to-let building sites. There were some tourist maps that showed the downtown area and a few primary arterial routes, but there was nothing available that had both the necessary scale for a walker – 1:25,000 or better – and sufficiently accurate orientation to enable compass bearings. While the local Bedouin may to this day retain a mental map of the area, collating a myriad of little positional markers – environmental, solar and sidereal – in order to determine location and direction, everyone else presumably relied on the GPS navigation systems in their air-conditioned cars.</p><p>In the end I hit on the simple if deranging idea of laying a 12in ruler against a Google Earth satellite photograph of the desert on my computer screen. This did indeed give me a means of dead-reckoning, but I had no way of determining distance accurately, and when I left the last pile of dusty breezeblocks behind and headed into the dunes, following the flickering needle of my compass, it was with the understanding I might well be spending the night beneath the stars. In fact, the bearing proved sound enough, and I arrived at the resort hotel well after dark to be informed by the receptionist (who was from Selly Oak) that there’d be no alcohol served that night because it was the Prophet’s birthday.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/may/04/pinpoint-how-gps-is-changing-our-world-greg-milner-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/03/tim-cook-iphone-model-upgrade</link>
      <description><p>Apple CEO says fears over company’s future are a ‘huge overreaction’ and claims in a few years the Apple Watch will be viewed as an overnight success</p><p>Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, has attempted to assuage fears over the company’s fall in earnings, saying that the dip in stock price was a “huge overreaction” and that forthcoming iPhones will make people look back and ask “how did I live without this?”<br></p><p>Cook described the 26% year-on-year drop in revenues Apple suffered last quarter and the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/29/billionaire-investor-carl-icahn-sells-entire-stake-in-apple">trouble in China which caused the billionaire investor Carl Icahn to sell his entire stake</a> in the company as “short-term turbulence”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/03/tim-cook-iphone-model-upgrade">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Italian investigators cannot unlock iPhone of alleged Bari terror ring suspect</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/11/italy-iphone-bari-terror-ring-suspect</link>
      <description><p>Officials face setback similar to that of FBI after San Bernardino shooting, as other suspects’ phones showed alleged evidence of ‘inspections’ of various sites</p><p>Italian investigators have been unable to unlock the Apple iPhone 6 plus of a suspect involved in an alleged <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/two-held-italian-terror-plot-inquiry-bari-london">terror ring in Bari</a>, in a development that mirrored a similar setback faced by US law enforcement officials following the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/san-bernardino-shooting">San Bernadino</a> attack.</p><p>The development raises the prospects of another <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/feb/22/tim-cook-apple-refusal-unlock-iphone-fbi-civil-liberties">standoff between Apple and officials involved in a terror investigation</a>, after the California technology company staunchly <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/mar/29/apple-victory-battle-fbi-but-war-continues-san-bernardino-iphone">refused to cooperate with US investigators</a> seeking to pull information from the phone that belonged to San Bernadino gunman Syed Farook.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/11/italy-iphone-bari-terror-ring-suspect">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The inside story of Facebook’s biggest setback | Rahul Bhatia</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/facebook-free-basics-india-zuckerberg</link>
      <description><p>The social network had a grand plan to connect millions of Indians to the internet. Here’s how it all went wrong</p><p>Until Mark Zuckerberg arrived in a bright orange helicopter in October 2014, Chandauli had never seen a celebrity visitor. One of 44,795 villages in the state of Rajasthan, Chandauli is only three or four hours’ drive from Delhi, but it exists alone and forgotten, tucked away, a kilometre off a quiet highway. Last year, when a local boy used the internet to buy a used motorcycle, astonished villagers called him an online shopping hero.</p><p>Zuckerberg had come to see an experiment at work. Earlier that year, with its sights set on the forthcoming elections, the government had asked a foundation to help give Chandauli’s mostly Muslim villagers a digital education. And so, with uncommon haste, a small administrative building was turned into a community centre, where locals could learn how to access email and find information online. Soon, almost every household in the village had one person who knew how to use a computer.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/facebook-free-basics-india-zuckerberg">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Battlefield 1: turning brutal WW1 combat into an enjoyable video game</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/09/battlefield-1-ea-dice-ww1-combat-video-game</link>
      <description><p>The series is going back to the first world war, and while EA Dice creative director Lars Gustavsson is intrigued by the design, its historical challenges are the most pressing concern</p><p>It’s been rumoured for months, but on Friday, Electronic Arts confirmed that the next title in its Battlefield series of military shooters will be set during the first world war. While the rival Call of Duty titles have been marching ever further into the future, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/06/battlefield-takes-military-shooter-games-back-to-first-world-war">Battlefield 1</a> is an attempt to re-engage with fans of the genre, who fell for titles like Battlefield 1942, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/gamesblog/2010/oct/13/medal-of-honor-review">Medal of Honor</a> and the original Call of Duty games with their depiction of historically authentic scenarios.</p><p>“This was the dawn of all-out war, the switch from the old world to the new world,” says creative director Lars Gustavsson. “Battlefield has always been about the land, sea and air war experience. This was something we had to do.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/09/battlefield-1-ea-dice-ww1-combat-video-game">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Inside the bootcamps where YouTube grows its next generation of stars</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/06/how-youtube-makes-its-next-generation-stars</link>
      <description><p>What is it like to be a NextUp contest winner, one of 16 hopefuls chosen as emerging stars by YouTube and trained to be the next PewDiePie or Zoella</p><p>“If people are learning about John Stuart Mill and what he thought about utilitarianism, that’s fine. Nobody really gets angry about that. But if you’re talking about critical gender theory, or critical race theory or feminism or transphobia, that’s when people get a lot more touchy … ”</p><p>Olly Lennard may not be your idea of an average YouTuber. Rather than playing games or giving makeup tips, his channel dishes out the syllabus from his masters degree in philosophy, one 5-10 minute video at a time.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/06/how-youtube-makes-its-next-generation-stars">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>_9MOTHER9HORSE9EYES9: the mysterious tale terrifying Reddit</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/05/9mother9horse9eyes9-the-mysterious-tale-terrifying-reddit</link>
      <description><p>An intimidating story emerging on Reddit plays on the horror of the unknown lurking in plain sight among the tools we use for everyday dialogue</p><p>If you take enough LSD, can you build a portal to the divine? It sounds like a typical internet conspiracy theory, the kind of thing weirdos post in online communities isolated from the rest of the world. But it’s also a conceptual prompt for a new work of digital fiction – a cool, and deeply creepy story that is gaining a cult fanbase.</p><p>Two weeks ago, a user who <a href="http://motherboard.vice.com/read/9mother9horse9eyes9-is-reddits-new-terrifying-mystery">came to be known</a> as “_9MOTHER9HORSE9EYES9” posted a disjointed snippet of text in a comment on Reddit, a site where communities post articles, images, personal stories and more for threaded group discussions. The post, added almost as if by accident <a href="https://www.reddit.com/r/mildlyinteresting/comments/4ft8ag/the_cover_of_george_orwells_1984_becomes_less/d2c3fdv">to a thread about the cover of George Orwell’s 1984</a>, made claims about the CIA’s acid-fuelled “mind control experiment” programme, Project MKUltra, a common staple of paranoid theory. MKUltra was indeed a real programme, but other items the user mentioned – “restraint bed portals” and “flesh interfaces” – are not.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/05/9mother9horse9eyes9-the-mysterious-tale-terrifying-reddit">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Hyperloop One tests high-speed transport propulsion system</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/11/hyperloop-supersonic-train-test-propulsion-system</link>
      <description><p>Company carries out public track run of prototype that might one day rocket commuters between San Francisco and Los Angeles in a supersonic pod</p><p>Hyperloop, the supersonic transport system proposed by tech billionaire Elon Musk, has taken a tentative step towards reality with the first public test of a prototype propulsion system.</p><p>One of the companies vying to make the idea a reality, <a href="https://hyperloop-one.com">Hyperloop One</a>, which changed its name from Hyperloop Technologies on Wednesday to coincide with the open-air propulsion test in the Nevada desert, has also closed an $80m series B funding round which includes investment from the French national rail company SNCF.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/11/hyperloop-supersonic-train-test-propulsion-system">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The $20,000 iPod: vintage Apple products net the big bucks on eBay</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/11/vintage-apple-products-ipod-collectors-item-ebay</link>
      <description><p>Like baseball cards and Beanie Babies, old-school Apple products have become lucrative collectables that are selling online for thousands of dollars</p><p>If you are one of those people who hoards old electronics, then you might be able to cash in those iPods from the early 2000s for a few hundred dollars – or even tens of thousands. </p><p>Like baseball cards from the 60s, Star Wars figurines from the 80s, or Beanie Babies from the 90s, iPods from the early 2000s are becoming the latest collectible items to be trading at frankly ludicrous prices on auction sites like eBay – especially since Apple <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/sep/10/ipod-classic-apple-kills-mp3-player">announced</a> in September 2014 that it was discontinuing the iPod.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/11/vintage-apple-products-ipod-collectors-item-ebay">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Angry about Facebook censorship? Wait until you hear about the news feed</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/11/facebook-censorship-news-feed-trending-topics</link>
      <description><p>Peeved about Facebook’s curation of trending topics? Its news feed is reinventing censorship for a technological age, and humans need not apply</p><p>Bad news: Facebook is censoring the internet every day, warping your understanding of the world around you to benefit its corporate interests, and fundamentally changing the media landscape in a potentially apocalyptic fashion.</p><p>Good news: that has little to nothing to do with the fact that the human curators of its trending topics feature are a bit sniffy about linking to Breitbart News.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/11/facebook-censorship-news-feed-trending-topics">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Facebook controversy shows journalists are more complicated than algorithms</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/facebook-twitter-google-snapchat-news-bias</link>
      <description><p>Facebook, Twitter, Snapchat and Google have moved outside their comfort zone by trying to curate ‘unbiased’ news – but journalists aren’t like computers</p><p>Silicon Valley is trying to make the news business as neutral as its code. The problem is the humans.<br></p><p>Facebook learned this the hard way this week after a <a href="http://gizmodo.com/former-facebook-workers-we-routinely-suppressed-conser-1775461006">report</a> that staff it contracted to manage its “trending” articles section had suppressed certain stories, such pieces about Facebook or news of interest to conservative users.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/may/12/facebook-twitter-google-snapchat-news-bias">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Monica Lewinsky: ‘The shame sticks to you like tar’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/16/monica-lewinsky-shame-sticks-like-tar-jon-ronson</link>
      <description><p>Nearly 20 years ago, Monica Lewinsky found herself at the heart of a political storm. Now she’s turned that dark time into a force for good</p><p>One night in London in 2005, a woman said a surprisingly eerie thing to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/video/2014/may/07/monica-lewinsky-bill-clinton-affair-video">Monica Lewinsky</a>. Lewinsky had moved from New York a few days earlier to take a master’s in social psychology at the London School of Economics. On her first weekend, she went drinking with a woman she thought might become a friend. “But she suddenly said she knew really high-powered people,” Lewinsky says, “and I shouldn’t have come to London because I wasn’t wanted there.”</p><p>Lewinsky is telling me this story at a table in a quiet corner of a West Hollywood hotel. We had to pay extra for the table to be curtained off. It was my idea. If we hadn’t done it, passersby would probably have stared. Lewinsky would have noticed the stares and would have clammed up a little. “I’m hyper-aware of how other people may be perceiving me,” she says.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2016/apr/16/monica-lewinsky-shame-sticks-like-tar-jon-ronson">Continue reading...</a></description>
